25463: Vizzerdrix.author: Radagast
25463: Vizzerdrix.text_parsed:
Terrible and insane. It's not as if blue's creatures at the time were overpowered, so they stripped out the Mahamoti Djinn from the base set and added this crazy thing which makes no sense at all. It's a huge pink bunny... in blue... with no abilities... that takes too much to cast.

Had this silly critter appeared in one set, it would be have been a normal mistake, but how it stuck around for several core sets as a staggering example of a completely useless and out of flavor card is beyond me. Trained Orgg, it's worthless red twin, is at least "sort of" in flavor for red (a big ground creature and an Orgg), but even that doesn't excuse how bad it is. This thing has no excuse.

25475: Monstrous Growth.text_posted: I'm stumped and have a question here. I have 4 copies of this card. One is from the Portal set, and one is Starter 2000. The other 2 are where I'm running in to a problem. They have the squirrel picture, which means they must be from Starter 1999, Starter 2000, or Portal Second Age. They have a black line separating the text, which rules out 2000. They also have a star for the edition, and the artists name centered, which [i]should[/i] mean they're 1999. However, they have a [b]white[/b] border like 2000, instead of the black border it shows for 1999. Thoughts anyone? Did I find some misprints? Fluke copies? Or is the border being both colors in one printing common? And if it makes them any different, does it change the price on them at all? Thanks!

25475: Monstrous Growth.author: marmaris74

@lordalvon
Many green powerups have animals (especially squirrels) in their pictures. For example Might of Oaks (the Urza's legacy version) also does. The reason for is squirrel is probably because most people understand how small a squirrel is and so it is easy to see just how much it has grown (compared to what it usually is).

@thegatekeeper
Yes, you should. Then laugh evilly. As you attack into your opponent's nightstalker.

25493: Durkwood Boars.author: jfre81
25493: Durkwood Boars.text_parsed:
Early on in my Magic days, one of my classmates presented to me a card that "showed" that the game was "Satanic." And that card was none other than.......Durkwood Boars!

Not even Lord of the Pit or the old prints of Unholy Strength.

Yes, to him, the Boars might as well have had "666" etched in their heads. He was convinced that the Bible flavor text meant the Boars were possessed by the devil.

I paid it no mind, but I think of that every time I see those old Boars in my box-o'-cards-I-don't-really-use-anymore.

25497: Stone Rain.author: Paolino
25497: Stone Rain.text_parsed:
@A3Kitsune
Starter 2000 is composed by what follows.
1) A box with two 22 cards decks, two 15 cards boosters (all preconstructed), a premium version of Rhox from Nemesis and other things which are not cards.
2) A sampler pack released in magazines.
The cards which compose this "set" are from Sixth Edition, Starter 1999 and Portal. The cards from Portal and Starter 1999 differ from the original in that they have 1993-2000 copyright and no expansion symbol, while the cards from Sixth Edition are real Sixth Edition cards, and cannot be distinguished from the ones you can find in Sixth Edition products.
So, this image actually shows a Starter 2000 (and/or Sixth Edition) Stone Rain.

25499: Python.author: Atali
25499: Python.text_parsed:
Vampire Nighthawk is not an example of power creep compared to Python. Python is common and Vampire Nighthawk is uncommon.

Barony Vampire, Moriok Reaver, Warpath Ghoul, Bog Raiders, and Contagious Nim are some examples of power creep compared to Python.

Many of Python's contemporary cards in the 3 mana black slot were significantly better than it as well, and cards that predate it like Lim-Dûl's High Guard are better as well.

Bottom line, using Python as a point of comparison for modern power creep isn't fair, Python has always been terrible.
25499: Python.text_posted:
[autocard]Vampire Nighthawk[/autocard] is not an example of power creep compared to [autocard]Python[/autocard]. [autocard]Python[/autocard] is common and [autocard]Vampire Nighthawk[/autocard] is uncommon.

[autocard]Barony Vampire[/autocard], [autocard]Moriok Reaver[/autocard], [autocard]Warpath Ghoul[/autocard], [autocard]Bog Raiders[/autocard], and [autocard]Contagious Nim[/autocard] are some examples of power creep compared to [autocard]Python[/autocard].

Many of [autocard]Python[/autocard]'s contemporary cards in the 3 mana black slot were significantly better than it as well, and cards that predate it like [autocard]Lim-Dûl's High Guard[/autocard] are better as well.

Bottom line, using [autocard]Python[/autocard] as a point of comparison for modern power creep isn't fair, Python has always been terrible.
